metadata.title: Massachusetts Benefits Fraud & Mismanagement
metadata.description: Comprehensive data on SNAP fraud, unemployment fraud, and program mismanagement in Massachusetts

mainCase.headline: $7 Million SNAP Trafficking Scheme

defendants.name: Antonio Bonheur
defendants.notes: Also fraudulently obtained $10,821 in personal SNAP benefits while running store

redFlags: Single cash register with no scanner
No wholesale invoices in financial records

mainCase.howItWorked: Customers exchanged EBT cards for cash (e.g., $120 in SNAP for $100 cash). Store also sold liquor and MannaPack meals (humanitarian food intended for overseas distribution) for SNAP benefits.
oversightFailures: USDA visited store in 2021, 2024, and 2025 - fraud continued
DTA approved Bonheur for personal SNAP despite owning store with millions in redemptions
No verification of Bonheur's claimed '$0.00 income' on application
Massachusetts refused to share SNAP data with federal investigators

identityTheftCase.headline: $1.1 Million Multi-State SNAP & Unemployment Fraud

defendants.name: Raul Fernandez Vicioso
defendants.citizenship: Naturalized US citizen from Dominican Republic

defendants.name: Joel Vicioso Fernandez
defendants.citizenship: Green card holder from Dominican Republic

identityTheftCase.detection: Rhode Island officials detected fraud in June 2024 when 117 SNAP applications came from just 2 apartments
identityTheftCase.evidence: Counterfeit passports, EBT cards, handwritten lists of 100+ identities found at restaurant and residence

usAttorney.speaker: U.S. Attorney Leah Foley
usAttorney.text: This case exposes a serious breakdown in oversight. The Massachusetts Department of Transitional Assistance conducted virtually no due diligence when reviewing his application.

usda.speaker: USDA Spokesperson
usda.text: As expected, the Governor will blame anyone but her administration for this massive dereliction of duty.

critic.speaker: Citizens Against Eversource founder Elijah DeSousa
critic.text: Gov. Healey is literally gaslighting us.

bilionDollarMistake.headline: $2.1 Billion Repayment to Federal Government
bilionDollarMistake.cause: Baker administration improperly used federal pandemic relief funds to cover state unemployment benefits

trustFundStatus.currentStatus: Expected to be hundreds of millions in the red by 2028
trustFundStatus.previousBailout: $2.7 billion in bonds sold in 2022 to repay Treasury loans
trustFundStatus.employerAssessment: Up to $3 billion in special assessment on employers

findings: DUA paid PUA benefits to incarcerated individuals
DUA paid benefits to state employees who were ineligible
System described as 'a dinosaur' by officials

healey.text: It is incredibly frustrating that the prior administration allowed this to happen.

retailersAssociation.speaker: Jon Hurst, Retailers Association of Massachusetts
retailersAssociation.text: The Massachusetts UI system is arguably the most abused, costly and anti-employer system in the country.

nfib.speaker: Christopher Carlozzi, NFIB Massachusetts
nfib.text: It is incomprehensible that the state made a monumental error, and it's Massachusetts small employers that are required to today foot the $2.1 billion bill.

patternOfMismanagement.title: A Pattern of Waste
patternOfMismanagement.summary: Massachusetts government has demonstrated repeated failures in financial oversight across multiple programs

totalWaste.note: Does not include ongoing fraud that hasn't been detected

commonThemes: Lack of basic verification (income, identity, eligibility)
Refusal to share data with federal investigators
No-bid contracts and lack of competitive procurement
Reactive rather than proactive fraud detection
Blame-shifting between state and federal agencies
Years of warnings ignored before action taken

healeyDefense.onSnapFraud: My administration reported this suspicious activity to the federal government for investigation over a year ago.
healeyDefense.onUnemployment: It is incredibly frustrating that the prior administration allowed this to happen.

federalCriticism.usAttorney: Massachusetts refused to turn over SNAP data... There is no privacy right that protects your fraudulent criminal behavior.
federalCriticism.usda: Massachusetts' DTA conducted virtually no due diligence

dataSharing.issue: Massachusetts is among Democratic-led states refusing to share SNAP recipient data with federal government
dataSharing.stateArgument: Privacy concerns, claim existing systems are sufficient
dataSharing.federalArgument: Cannot investigate fraud without data access
dataSharing.legalStatus: Federal judge temporarily blocked Trump administration's data demand in October 2025
